page.title: 03LOW FLYING AIRCRAFT
page.content: {LOW FLYING AIRCRAFT OVER GAINFORD} On 8th May 1985 it was reported in the {Teesdale Mercury,}that a low flying aircraft zoomed so close to{Snow {Hall,}near Gainford, that windows smashed and a horse bolted onto the main road. A{R.A.F.}officer and the {Department of Environment}are trying to trace the pilot and the aircraft. The owner of{Snow Hall,}protested to the{Ministry of Defence,}that the aeroplane was flying dangerously low. The horse, however, damaged a wall. Gainford residents have complained before about low flying aircraft. Gainford seems to be on the flight path for these{Harrier, Jaguar}and {Tornado}aircraft. Inhabitants of the village appreciate the need to train pilots in low flying and are prepared to tolerate some disturbance but not if damage to property is caused.
